docs.lead_paragraph: Cesar Chavez's son-in-law, Arturo Rodriguez, wants to put ''la causa'' back into America's vocabulary. Mr. Rodriguez, who became president of the United Farm Workers of America after his legendary father-in-law died in 1993, insists that the union's struggle is just as compelling today as in the union's heyday three decades ago, when millions of Americans embraced the downtrodden farm worker as a cause as holy as civil rights.

headline.main: Chavez's Son-in-Law Tries to Rebuild Legacy

docs.abstract: Interview with Arturo Rodriguez, president of United Farm Workers of America, and son-in-law of late founder Cesar Chavez, who says he wants to rebuild father-in-law's legacy; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Cesar Chavez's son-in-law, Arturo Rodriguez, wants to put ''la causa'' back into America's vocabulary.    Mr. Rodriguez, who became president of the United Farm Workers of America after his legendary father-in-law died in 1993, insists that the...

docs.lead_paragraph: WANTED: auditor. Technology company, former target of class-action lawsuit, under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, has lost two Big Six accounting firms within the last year. Needs to resolve questions over its financial statements. Quickly. When Pinnacle Micro Inc. announced in February 1996 that Coopers & Lybrand had quit as its auditor less than a year after Ernst & Young had resigned, its stock plummeted nearly 40 percent. Even so, Pinnacle's former chief executive, William F. Blum, assured investors that management was ''confident'' about the future and would find a new auditor shortly.

headline.main: Why Some Auditors Like the Taste of Leftovers

docs.abstract: BDO Seidman, ninth-largest accounting firm in US, has emerged as national firm that has inherited greatest number of castoff companies; from January 1994 through early June, BDO was hired by companies representing 43 of 546 resignations tracked by Public Accounting Report; table (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN other boxing eras, the names on the fight posters were enough to sell tickets: Ali-Frazier, Marciano-Walcott, Louis-Schmeling, Dempsey-Tunney. Now the big fights, like movies and plays, have marquee titles befitting their show-biz market.
docs.abstract: Dave Anderson Sports of The Times column on need for Professional Boxing Safety Act, which takes effect July 1; says it imposes standards of safety that include health insurance for each boxer as well as physical exam, ringside physician and ambulance or medical personnel with resuscitation equipment on site; notes that Sen John McCain, who spearheaded bill, is concerned about journeymen boxers who strive to succeed despite their usually disadvantaged background; photo (M)
docs.snippet: IN other boxing eras, the names on the fight posters were enough to sell tickets: Ali-Frazier, Marciano-Walcott, Louis-Schmeling, Dempsey-Tunney. Now the big fights, like movies and plays, have marquee titles befitting their show-biz market.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dec. 19, 1996 -- I got my first mammogram today at a place called the Breast Health Center in San Francisco. I've never really considered whether I had healthy breasts. Healthy knees, yes. Healthy gums, maybe. But healthy breasts? I don't even do self-exams, except when I read something about cancer in the paper.

headline.main: 35 and Mortal: A Breast Cancer Diary

docs.abstract: Peggy Orenstein article presents her diary entries since having her first mammogram at age 35 and discovering that she has breast cancer; they relate her decision to have a lumpectomy and radiation therapy, joining a support group for women under 40 with breast cancer and her coming to terms with her disease; photos (L)
